Adrenal vein sampling can distinguish whether the elevated levels of aldosterone are due to an adenoma or hyperplasia of the adrenal gland. If it’s an adenoma, right adrenalectomy is the appropriate treatment. If it’s hyperplasia, bilateral adrenalectomy or spironolactone therapy may be options.

Adrenal vein sampling can determine which adrenal gland is producing excess aldosterone, which can guide further treatment choices. Spironolactone therapy can be used to treat excess aldosterone but surgery is recommended for adenomas.

Adrenal vein sampling (AVS) is the most accurate test to determine unilateral or bilateral production of aldosterone. Bilateral adrenalectomy is not typically the first choice of treatment, and spironolactone therapy and right adrenalectomy require more information from AVS. Therefore, AVS is the most appropriate next step in management.

The adrenal mass found on the CT scan is likely the cause of the aldosterone excess. Adrenal vein sampling is necessary to identify whether the aldosterone excess is from the right adrenal gland or the left adrenal gland, as this will determine which adrenal gland needs to be removed during surgery. Spironolactone therapy may be an option for patients who cannot undergo surgery, but surgery is preferred for patients with a solitary adrenal mass. Bilateral adrenalectomy is only considered in patients with bilateral adrenal hyperplasia.
